results.title: The Magic scarab: superstition
results.creator_credit: Marshall Izen and Coronet Instructional Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Forest town fables”.
This film uses a puppet story to explore the fallacy of belief in superstition, emphasizing self-reliance. It shows how Oni and the other puppets find out whether or not a good-luck charm really works when Oni reluctantly enters the spelling contest without it. Awards: two Emmy awards. Voices by Ruth Franklin and Marshall Izen. Suitable for lower and middle primary levels.
results.description:

results.title: The Treasure hunt: teamwork
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Forest town fables”.
Presents a puppet show story about teamwork on a treasure hunt in order to show the value of working together to meet a common goal.

results.title: Taffy's imagination: fear of the dark
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Forest town fables”.
One of a series of six Forest Town Fables, this film presents realistic explanations of imagined fantasies, so that darkness can be faced with confidence. It explains that Taffy is afraid of the dark until her puppet friends teach her their night game. It also shows how she discovers that things she saw and heard were imagined. Suitable for lower and middle primary levels.

results.title: Celebrations: birthdays
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “For the juniors”.
A short program aimed at children aged 4-8 discussing the different aspects of preparing for and celebrating a birthday, comparing a traditional birthday party for an Australian child to a German and an Asian child. Also shows how people of all ages celebrate birthdays, and explains just what a birthday is.

results.title: Weather: dry
results.creator_credit: Caroline Jones and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “For the juniors”.
This educational video explains the dry weather and its characteristics. It explains humidity and the effects dry weather has on farms and nature. The video talks of drought and how animals can adapt to periods of dry weather and also the effects of water wastage and conservation. Koalas and camels feature.

results.title: Weather: hot
results.creator_credit: Caroline Jones and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “For the juniors”.
An educational series aimed at 6-8 year olds which covers a variety of subject areas such as weather, transport, space, people and celebrations. When it is hot outside, people wear shorts and t-shirts, drink lots of water, and modify their usual activities to help keep cool. The question is why do we do this? Suitable for children aged 3-7, this video describes how changes in weather affect people, plants and animals differently and the different methods each use to adapt and cope with the heat; what a thermometer is and what it does; how to observe and monitor changes in the weather; and why it is important to dress appropriately when it is hot outside. Also briefly discusses the sun as an energy source.

results.title: Weather: sunshine
results.creator_credit: Janet Lane and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “For the juniors”.
An educational series aimed at 6-8 year olds which covers a variety of subject areas such as weather, transport, space, people and celebrations. This short video describes how the sun creates shadows on the ground and reflections on the water; how as the world rotates, the sun sets on one side of the world and rises on the other; and how people and animals use the sun differently. Suitable for children aged 3-7.

results.title: Weather: cold
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “For the juniors”.
This educational video for children covers the topic of cold weather. There are scenes of frosty mornings and the reasons why nights can be so cold, especially when they are cloudless. There are ways and reasons to stay warm and how animals like sheep and horses keep warm during the cold months. The video explains how penguins and whales stay warm, mentioning migration and hibernation as ways animals survive the cold weather. Cold weather and seasons are also important to explain why you can’t buy vegetables all year round.
